bug.short_desc: Compiler incorrectly reports error message "X cannot be resolved. It is indirectly referenced from required .class files"

long_desc.thetext:
Created attachment 232112 Reduced Test Case
I know there other bugs related to this message (ie. 239639, 320965, 391528) but this issue deals with backward compatibility with JDK 1.4 'built' jars.
Steps to reproduce the problem: 1. Import the two projects from the attached zip J14 (1.4 level) J16 (1.6 level) 2. Export J14 as a jar 3. Bring up the properties for J16 and add the jar to its Java build path. 4. Open the Main class in J16 using the Java Editor --> You will see the errror message 5. If you run the Main class as a Java Application, it works as expected. This shows backward compatibility of 1.4 level jars.
The error message is misleading because the type/class is actually present in the jar.
Note that the J14 project has a package with the 'enum' keyword in its name.

(In reply to comment #1) > Note that the J14 project has a package with the 'enum' keyword in its name.
Looks like there is problem with resolving Test since it is inside the disallowed package enum in 1.6. At this point, I don't know how complicated the fix is going to be, i.e. if we decide to fix it. By the way, if the JLS6 project is moved to JLS4 compliance, then things work alright.
I will take a closer look during 4.4
Thanks for the quick response. Changing the compliance level is currently not an acceptable workaround. We want the compliance level to be at least 1.5 or higher.

I don't see how you can refer to a type that has a package name that contains "enum" with a compliance greater or equal to 1.5. Starting with 1.5, "enum" is a keyword and no longer an identifier. So it is illegal inside a package name. What kind of resolution do you expect here ? How does javac behave on this ?

Tested with the following command-line, javac compiles the code without diagnostics:
C:\Users\Timo\Downloads\ReducedTestcase\J16>"c:\Program Files (x86)\Java\jdk1.7.0_13\bin\javac.exe" -sourcepath src -cp J14.jar -d bin src\p\Main.java
This makes sense, because the code being compiled doesn't mention the class p.enum.Test, like the error says it is only indirectly referenced from already compiled class files. Here's the errors I see, these actually don't have corresponding entries in the Problems-view:
Multiple markers at this line - The method setTest(Test) from the type Test2 refers to the missing type Test - The type p.enum.Test cannot be resolved. It is indirectly referenced from required .class files
Reproduced in Juno Service Release 2 Build id: 20130225-0426

Created attachment 232378 Subsequent failure to open the class in class file viewer
This workspace has one class file viewer opened, but the view cannot be created successfully. This failure persists across closing and reopening Eclipse.

(In reply to comment #0) > Created attachment 232112 [details] > Reduced Test Case > > I know there other bugs related to this message (ie. 239639, 320965, 391528) > but this issue deals with backward compatibility with JDK 1.4 'built' jars. > > Steps to reproduce the problem: > 1. Import the two projects from the attached zip > J14 (1.4 level) > J16 (1.6 level) > 2. Export J14 as a jar > 3. Bring up the properties for J16 and add the jar to its Java build path. > 4. Open the Main class in J16 using the Java Editor > --> You will see the errror message > 5. If you run the Main class as a Java Application, it works as expected. > This shows backward compatibility of 1.4 level jars. > > The error message is misleading because the type/class is actually present > in the jar.
The error message mentioned in comment 0 appears only as a marker in the Java editor, there is no error in the Problems view. That means there is a difference between running compiler as part of the build and as part of the reconciler.

(In reply to comment #8) > The error message mentioned in comment 0 appears only as a marker in the > Java editor, there is no error in the Problems view. That means there is a > difference between running compiler as part of the build and as part of the > reconciler.
Yes, the problem is only with the reconciler and not the compiler. We need to find out why.

(In reply to comment #9) > (In reply to comment #8) > > The error message mentioned in comment 0 appears only as a marker in the > > Java editor, there is no error in the Problems view. That means there is a > > difference between running compiler as part of the build and as part of the > > reconciler. > > Yes, the problem is only with the reconciler and not the compiler. We need > to find out why.
I will take a look, if you don't mind.

(In reply to comment #10) > I will take a look, if you don't mind.
No, we don't mind at all. In fact, you are more than welcome to provide a patch if you can. TIA!

The reason why errors are shown only for the reconciler is that it uses SearchableEnvironment as INameEnvironment whereas the compiler uses NameEnvironment.
SearchableEnvironment uses project cache to look up for types and the cache is created only for types valid for compliance defined in project's preferences. 'enum' is not valid for JDK>=1.5 so SearchableEnvironment cannot find the class. NameEnvironment simply opens all jars on the classpath one by one looking for the type without any additional name validation, thus no error is shown for compiler.
I tried to cheat SearchableEnvironment to open the jar in 1.4 mode (see JarPackageFragmentRoot.computeChildren(...)), but there were side effects - I could insert p.enum.Test using code assist which should not be possible.

Created attachment 232484 Class with invalid package name
You can actually tell when a class will not be found by the reconciler by looking at how the class is represented in Package Explorer. Changing the compliance to 1.6 will also change the way how the class is presented.

I think that one possible solution would be to mimic behaviour of NameEnvironment i.e. consider all packages without name validation for resolving types referred from BinaryTypeBindings.
The rationale behind this change would be that if a type is already resolved as BinaryTypeBinding it means a class file was found for this type, and that means all types used within this class must have been resolved correctly at the compilation time. There is no point to narrow down the list of packages if project's JDK level is different than class file's. Ideally, we could use separate name environments for types that have different JDK levels than the project (e.g. by maintaining separate name environments for each JDK level that is used, not only the global one for the project).
Jay/Srikanth, what do you think?
See also bug 330537.

I spent the last two weeks trying to implement something that would work, but no success. Here are my observations.
There are two errors reported: - The method setTest(Test) from the type Test2 refers to the missing type Test - The type p.enum.Test cannot be resolved. It is indirectly referenced from required .class files
Fixing the first one seems to be relatively easy because "null" is always a correct argument for non-base types, even if the type is unresolved. The hard part is the second error. Conclusions about the second error:
1. Compiler is not affected because it doesn't use model, only model-based name lookups are affected which means similar problems may happen anywhere model is used.
2. Packages with "enum" (and other invalid names in the given source/compiler compliance) cannot be part of the model because of point 3 below, but are necessary to resolve types using the model. At the moment, folder inside a jar can have two flavors: package or regular folder. For this bug we would probably need to have a mix of these two - incompatible package fragment (e.g. something like NonCompliantJarPackageFragment) to be able to resolve types, but behaving like a folder and not visible outside.
3. Accepting all packages without initial name validation looks like a no-go, because we would be hit by validation later on (like the fix for bug 108456) or by inconsistent model leading to incorrect code assist proposals (comment 12).
4. Implementing multi-dimension name environments (comment 14) sounds also like a no-go, because in the end we may need to allow compiling different parts of project with different compliance (see e.g. bug 87215, bug bug 105372).
All in all, looks like a tough one...
Created attachment 233078 Partial fix
Please ignore my previous comment. When I wrote it down, it came to me that there is another possible solution.

Created attachment 233128 Patch v.0.1
Fix and test for this issue. If you want to test it without fix for bug 412400, you need to change compliance in the test from 1.6 to 1.5. I'm now running all JDT core tests to see it there are no side effects.

(In reply to comment #19) > I'm now running all JDT core tests to see if there are no side effects.
There is one test that fails with this change: org.eclipse.jdt.core.tests.model.CompletionTests2.testBug317264c() and it is also about "enum". Investigating further...

Created attachment 233264 Patch v.0.2
It looks there is a long history of problems with "enum" packages, bug 317264 being on the top of the iceberg...
Since the reconciler needs to be aware of types in packages that are not valid for current's project compliance, my proposed solution is to add those packages to the model and then filter out in code assist and other places where it is not valid to refer to a type from a non-compliant package. Please note that the problem happens not only for jar packages bug also for regular packages (test for this case is also added).
I have narrowed down changes to those related to this bug only. You will get CompletionTests2.testBug317264c() failure with this patch which should be handled before releasing but I'd like to get your opinion on the approach presented in the patch before modifying the code assist code.

(written before I saw comment 22)
Hi Szymon, from a quick look the patch in itself looks fine to me. BTW, lookup of the IJavaProject can be abbreviated by using JavaCore.create(IProject) :)
Let me rephrase the consequences, to check whether I understand correctly: - the java model can now contain package fragments that have a name illegal in the current project, as long as it was legal in the containing jar / folder. - no source of the current project will be able to refer to that package fragment - indirect references should be OK - care must be taken that the semi-legal name will never find its way into sources of the current project (e.g., as an import, or as a qfn during completion): - for completion you suggest filtering (completion mostly works with names, not IJavaElement; so do you plan to check names for compliance again, like in CompletionEngine.isForbiddenType()?) - similar adaptation would be needed in ImportRewrite and friends - other? Think of wizards that ask for super type, any operation that creates source based on types available in the current scope. I'm afraid there may not be a single point of reference to avoid leaking of semi-legal names into source, is there?
This situation reminds me of OSGi related issues like bug 148844, where an exported class of bundle A refers in a method signature to a class from bundle B, which is imported by A, but not re-exported. A client C, importing A, will be able to see a method with a type in its signature that is not known to the client. In that context I was thinking of flagging the *method* as inaccessible rather than reporting the infamous "indirectly referenced" error. We were reluctant to implement a full solution because of possible impact on overload resolution, e.g.
Do you see the similarity, or is this bug a different story entirely?

(In reply to comment #23) > Hi Szymon, from a quick look the patch in itself looks fine to me. > BTW, lookup of the IJavaProject can be abbreviated by using > JavaCore.create(IProject) :)
Hi Stephan, thanks for the review and the hint! I will use it in the next version.
> Let me rephrase the consequences, to check whether I understand correctly: > - the java model can now contain package fragments that have a name illegal > in the current project, as long as it was legal in the containing jar / > folder. > - no source of the current project will be able to refer to that package > fragment > - indirect references should be OK
3 x Yes.
> - care must be taken that the semi-legal name will never find its way into > sources of the current project (e.g., as an import, or as a qfn during > completion): > - for completion you suggest filtering (completion mostly works with names, > not IJavaElement; so do you plan to check names for compliance again, > like in CompletionEngine.isForbiddenType()?)
Yes, exactly. I will attach a sample that fixes failure in CompletionTests2.testBug317264c() to show how I plan to fix it. We should use similar fixes in other places as mentioned in comment 22.
> - similar adaptation would be needed in ImportRewrite and friends
I didn't know about that. Will do.
> - other? Think of wizards that ask for super type, any operation that > creates source based on types available in the current scope. I'm afraid > there may not be a single point of reference to avoid leaking of > semi-legal names into source, is there?
I think you're right, there are many of them but it should be feasible to fix them all (we are still in M1 so there is a lot of time :-) ). Another example that I found: for testing purposes I've created an exception p.enum.TestException that extends java.lang.Exception. When you use a method that throws this exception, you are forced to wrap it in try-catch but you cannot refer directly to this type so the quick fix should understand it and propose the first legal super-type of the actual exception, in this case java.lang.Exception.
But that's not what I'm concerned about (am I naive? ;-) ). The thing that I'm mostly concerned is the search part since other bugs fixing similar issues where limited by performance concerns (bug 317264 being a very good example). I think we need to prepare ourselves to allow some justified impact on performance. There were many attempts to fix such bugs "once and for all", but it usually ended as a workaround, including dedicated fixes for a particular jar. The scenario with exception convinced me that we can't go with another workaround, e.g. like the one in comment 17.
> This situation reminds me of OSGi related issues like bug 148844, where an > exported class of bundle A refers in a method signature to a class from > bundle B, which is imported by A, but not re-exported. A client C, importing > A, will be able to see a method with a type in its signature that is not > known to the client. > In that context I was thinking of flagging the *method* as inaccessible > rather than reporting the infamous "indirectly referenced" error. We were > reluctant to implement a full solution because of possible impact on overload > resolution, e.g. > > Do you see the similarity, or is this bug a different story entirely?
Yes, I see some analogy here, but I think the difference is that in this bug the builder doesn't report any problem while in bug 148844 it can't compile it at all.
Created attachment 233267 Initial fix for CompletionEngine

(In reply to comment #24) > Yes, I see some analogy here, but I think the difference is that in this bug > the builder doesn't report any problem while in bug 148844 it can't compile > it at all.
In other words, in case of this bug we have all dependencies available, the only problem is that our model doesn't want to accept some of them, thus the reconciler behaves differently than the builder.

(In reply to comment #24) > (In reply to comment #23) > > Hi Szymon, from a quick look the patch in itself looks fine to me. > > BTW, lookup of the IJavaProject can be abbreviated by using > > JavaCore.create(IProject) :) > > Hi Stephan, thanks for the review and the hint! I will use it in the next > version.
Marking Stephan as the reviewer and committer. TIA.

Created attachment 233314 Patch v.0.3
CompletionTests2.testBug317264c() is fixed by additional validation in CompletionEngine.acceptPackage(char[]) before accepting the package. All JDT core tests green. Investigating the "ImportRewrite and friends" part.
One concern: since the root cause of bug 317264 was "Java Model Status <some enum> does not exist" and now the "enum" types and packages will be allowed, should we revisit bug 317264 and fix/revert it if it is not correct any more? The "enum" types are valid everywhere but source so there is no point in filtering it out early in the search, only in places that can modify source e.g. code completion. I already tried to reproduce steps from bug 317264 comment 0, but was not able to get the error even with reverted fix for that bug so I'm not sure where we are the moment. Maybe there was another workaround committed somewhere that hides the original bug?

(In reply to comment #23) > - similar adaptation would be needed in ImportRewrite and friends
Stephan, I've fixed ImportRewrite to disallow the "enum" packages, but now I'm not sure what you meant by its friends? Do you mean ASTRewrite? If so, what would be the expected fix there?

(In reply to comment #29) > (In reply to comment #23) > > - similar adaptation would be needed in ImportRewrite and friends > > Stephan, I've fixed ImportRewrite to disallow the "enum" packages, but now > I'm not sure what you meant by its friends? Do you mean ASTRewrite? If so, > what would be the expected fix there?
I will try to answer myself: we could disallow to add ASTNode that contains a type with "enum" that can appear in the source because we would get incompatible content after rewrite. AST may contain compile errors but should always adhere to the grammar so we can safely reject any change that would violate the grammar. Does it make sense?
Created attachment 233467 Patch v.0.4

In order to adapt similar changes to ASTRewrite I had to modify SimpleName to use the exact source level of the CU to scan for valid identifiers. This worked fine as a proof of concept (quick fix changes adding "enum" as identifier were nicely rejected) but resulted in a test failure in ASTTest.testSimpleName(). Default source level for JLS4 is 1.7 so ASTTest.testSimpleName() failed when trying to add "assert" because the scanner rejected it as invalid identifier for 1.7. The bug where the special implementation of SimpleName.setIdentifier(String) was added is bug 343687.
I'm having hard time trying to understand why bug 343687 was fixed that way and why JLS API level is used to "calculate" source/compliance level. Source and compliance levels are used directly all over the place to tell what code we are dealing with so I'm not sure why JLS API level should hide that information and "calculate" it using fixed algorithm which then requires workaround like the one in bug 343687. It seems that AST should be parametrized using 3 params: JLS API level, source level and compliance level, so that it is truly possible to work with exactly given source level using latest JLS API. I've added proposed changes in the patch.
I have checked BETA_JAVA8 branch - there is a new JLS8 level added and source level is still calculated based on that.
Stephan, when you get a moment can you please comment on my findings summarized in comment 32 and comment 33? Thanks!

Hi Szymon,
sorry for the delay, I'm currently focused on "repairing" Object Teams for Luna, after recent changes in the osgi framework "killed" the existing implementation of OT/Equinox ... I hope to be back to JDT work soonish..

(In reply to comment #35) > Hi Szymon, > > sorry for the delay, I'm currently focused on "repairing" Object Teams for > Luna, > after recent changes in the osgi framework "killed" the existing > implementation > of OT/Equinox ... > I hope to be back to JDT work soonish..
Yep, I've been following the discussion on equinox-dev. Good luck with the migration!
Stephan, have you had a chance to take a look at the latest patch and my findings summarized in comment 32 and comment 33?

I'm finally looking into this ...
(In reply to comment #21) > It looks there is a long history of problems with "enum" packages, bug > 317264 being on the top of the iceberg...
Trying to study the history, I found that relevant parts of the patch from bug 317264 have been reverted via bug 327654.
(In reply to comment #24) > ... The thing that > I'm mostly concerned is the search part since other bugs fixing similar > issues where limited by performance concerns (bug 317264 being a very good > example). I think we need to prepare ourselves to allow some justified > impact on performance. There were many attempts to fix such bugs "once and > for all", but it usually ended as a workaround, including dedicated fixes > for a particular jar.
So you already looked at that bug, too.
> The scenario with exception convinced me that we can't > go with another workaround, e.g. like the one in comment 17.
so if we discard all the reasoning regarding a solution with good performance, we should at least come up with some measurements about the impact. At this point it really hurts that performance tests are out-of-commission :(
After a first round of retracing all comments and some related bugs I'll now start looking at the actual patches.

(In reply to comment #38) > I'm finally looking into this ...
Thanks!
> so if we discard all the reasoning regarding a solution with good > performance, > we should at least come up with some measurements about the impact. > At this point it really hurts that performance tests are out-of-commission :(
I'm far from discarding performance as one of the main concerns here. But I think that it would be better to come up with an ideal solution first and then discuss which parts of our ideal solution can be skipped to satisfy secondary concerns like performance. Who knows, maybe we can come up with a fix without any performance hit :)

(In reply to comment #39) > I'm far from discarding performance as one of the main concerns here. But I > think that it would be better to come up with an ideal solution first and > then discuss which parts of our ideal solution can be skipped to satisfy > secondary concerns like performance. Who knows, maybe we can come up with a > fix without any performance hit :)
Excellent.
BTW, did you ever understand the original worries about performance? What exactly would (perhaps) cause such forbidding penalties?
I had a tiny idea while studying the patch: - PackageFragment could perhaps cache the result of isValidPackageName()
Next, could you please comment on these:
(1) In the constructors of JarPackageFragmentRoot: why to you call getPath() immediately after assigning this.jarPath? Using this.jarPath looks simpler to read and perform, and seems to work, too. Right?
(2) In ImportRewrite, what's the idea behind letting validateImport() throw IAE? Who is supposed to catch that exception? How can we ensure that this exception doesn't fly into the user's face? :)
BTW: When saying "ImportRewrite and friends" I primarily thought of ImportRewriteAnalyser, but it looks like this guy is only called with names that have already been checked by ImportRewrite.
(3) If you have multiple variants of basically the same test I'm a fan of little comments that tell the reader about the purpose of each variation :)
Comments regarding your changes in DOM plus black-box testing will come in the next round.

(In reply to Stephan Herrmann from comment #40) > BTW, did you ever understand the original worries about performance? > What exactly would (perhaps) cause such forbidding penalties?
The only comment with performance numbers that I found is bug 317264 comment 28. It seems that performance of code completion was the main concern at that time.
> I had a tiny idea while studying the patch: > - PackageFragment could perhaps cache the result of isValidPackageName()
Yes. And also, JarPackageFragment could probably always return true as the same test was performed earlier in JarPackageFragmentRoot.initRawPackageInfo(..). I left those unoptimized deliberately because I'm not very familiar with model objects lifecycle (e.g. if same (Jar)PackageFragment could survive somewhere and be used for another build after build path change), and in general it is better to be told "please optimize it", than to get unexpected results. "Premature optimization is the root of all evil" ;) I will fix it for the next patch.
> Next, could you please comment on these: > > (1) In the constructors of JarPackageFragmentRoot: why to you > call getPath() immediately after assigning this.jarPath? Using this.jarPath > looks simpler to read and perform, and seems to work, too. Right?
Not really. getPath() is needed to distinguish between external and non-external jar files. See JarPackageFragmentRoot.internalPath().
> (2) In ImportRewrite, what's the idea behind letting validateImport() throw > IAE? > Who is supposed to catch that exception? How can we ensure that this > exception doesn't fly into the user's face? :)
I didn't understand what you had meant by "and friends", so I assumed it is about making sure that "enum" will never appear in source when modifying source programmatically using AST/DOM. That is why I made all those changes in the AST/DOM area. The exception is supposed to be handled by the code using DOM, so all JDT UI refactorings, quick fixes, etc. would need to understand it and perform valid AST modification instead. See my example with p.enum.TestException in comment 24. In general we can't ensure IAE "doesn't fly into the user's face". You can see that ImportRewrite can throw IAE on other occasions as well.
> (3) If you have multiple variants of basically the same test I'm a fan of > little comments that tell the reader about the purpose of each variation :)
I will add comments for the next patch.
Hi Stephan, are you waiting for me to attach next version of the patch with your suggestions from comment 40 or you are already reviewing the rest of the latest patch?

Created attachment 236448 Patch v.0.5
The patch addresses all issues raised so far.
This contribution complies with http://www.eclipse.org/legal/CoO.php
Is this patch looking like the right fix? I'm hoping to have it backported to R3_6_maintenance if possible.
Please review the code during M4. Thanks.
I spoke to Szymon during ECE and asserted that I definitely want to get it into Luna. I'll try to find some time during M4 (which is also the time frame for me to finish type inference for JSR 335).

I'm sorry, bug 400874 absorbed all my attention as of late.
In private communication I proposed to Szymon to address this patch first thing in January and he agreed to this schedule -> moving to M5.
I hope this is OK for everybody.

(In reply to Stephan Herrmann from comment #47) > I'm sorry, bug 400874 absorbed all my attention as of late. > > In private communication I proposed to Szymon to address this patch first > thing in January and he agreed to this schedule -> moving to M5. > > I hope this is OK for everybody.
Agreed. Java 8 has higher priority at the moment, put it would be good to review the patch for M5.

I finally (!!) found some time to review the latest patch (from comment 43). As expected most of it looks great.
I have a few nitpicks, still:
(1) CompletionEngine is using HashtableOfObject as a set, perhaps you want to change it to SimpleSetOfCharArray? (I see that there is precedent of using HashtableOfObject, but still ... :) )
(2) In ASTTest you check "this.API_LEVEL != AST.JLS4" which should probably be "this.API_LEVEL < AST.JLS4", right?
The parts regarding model and completion look good to me. Even navigation to a semi-legal class using text hovers works smoothly. Good!
I'm not yet convinced what the right strategy for DOM will be, and how to make all of JDT/UI cope with these semi-legal things:
When working with a project of the corresponding setup, I observed several quick assists/fixes to simply do nothing, while the logs had *warnings* from the IAE thrown in ImportRewrite; no visible response to the user: is this good or bad?
In case of some quick fixes this also caused the following to be logged as an *error*: java.lang.IllegalStateException: must specify at least one linked position at org.eclipse.jface.text.link.LinkedModeModel.enforceNotEmpty(LinkedModeModel.java:534)
This latter error can be toggled by reverting the changes in SimpleName.
Given these observations, given that the entire business around bug 343687 is quite unclear, I suggest the following: - for now retract some changes in the DOM part (not sure where exactly to draw the line, at least the change in SimpleName) - release the main part of the patch for M5 - file a new bug where we can co-operate with Markus so JDT/UI has a chance to "do the right thing"
@Markus, seeing you are already on Cc:, do you agree with this strategy, or do you have a quick comment that actually settles the issue around SimpleName accepting or not accepting "enum" as an identifier based on {ast level, compliance, source level}?

I agree the changes in the DOM AST are not necessary and shouldn't be released.
An unspecified IAE from the ImportRewrite is not helpful. E.g. when I have this line in the Main class and apply the quick fix ...
t.setTest(t);
... then I better get an invalid ...
import p.enum.Test;
... where the compile error immediately tells me what the problem is. The enum/assert keyword additions happened so long back in time that we won't spend resources in the UI to detect situations like this upfront and show a "proper" error message. (In contrast to the compiler, the UI just has to "survive".)
The goal of the DOM AST is not to find compile errors, but to serve as a basis for analysis and rewrite. For those tasks, it's better to have an AST that may not be 100% legal. After all, we also have AST recovery! SimpleName#setIdentifier(String) should actually accept *all* identifiers that have been *legal at any time* in the JLS history. There's no single source/scanner level for that, but JDK1_3 looks good enough for now. The intention of that check is not to find spec violations but to catch simple API user errors early on (like passing a qualified or parameterized name instead of a simple name).
> When working with a project of the corresponding setup, I observed several > quick assists/fixes to simply do nothing, while the logs had *warnings* from > the IAE thrown in ImportRewrite; no visible response to the user: is this > good or bad?
The warnings are from Quick Fix previews for unexpectable exceptions like this breaking API change. Good enough, IMO. See bug 141250.

Szymon, I'm sorry if I've encouraged you to spend time on parts of the patch that won't get released after all. Still the main part of the patch is ready for release. Just we need to decide what goes in and what doesn't.
Jay, maybe you can help us find the line?
This work has been made under the premises that - packages must be accepted in the model based on their original source/ compliance settings, not those of the referencing project. - those packages that have illegal names when used in the referencing project should "never" find their way into source code (code assist etc.)
Filtering semi-legal names during completion works nicely and should definitely be part of the patch.
Implementing more restrictive checks in SimpleName has already been voted down by Markus (previous comment).
The part which I'd call border-line is where ImportRewrite.addImport throws IllegalArgumentException. Szymon argues that these methods can already throw IAE for other situations. Apparently, different parts in JDT/UI react differently to this IAE.
Is it good to silently ignore such quick fixes that would create illegal code, or should we ask Szymon to withdraw that part and let the user just see the compile error after quick fix was successfully applied? The perfect solution where JDT/UI would explicitly handle this (rare) situation is over-sized (and thus won't happen) as per Markus' comment.
Szymon, do you have a minute to prepare a final patch on short notice?

(In reply to Stephan Herrmann from comment #51) > code, or should we ask Szymon to withdraw that part and let the user just > see the compile error after quick fix was successfully applied?
I am for this as long as the outcome of this discussion/future bug won't have much influence on what we would like to commit for this bug. In other words, if they are reasonably independent, we should go ahead and release, leaving out the addImport part for another bug.

(In reply to Stephan Herrmann from comment #49) > I have a few nitpicks, still: > > (1) CompletionEngine is using HashtableOfObject as a set, perhaps you want > to change it to SimpleSetOfCharArray? (I see that there is precedent of > using > HashtableOfObject, but still ... :) )
OK.
> (2) In ASTTest you check "this.API_LEVEL != AST.JLS4" which should probably > be "this.API_LEVEL < AST.JLS4", right?
DOM AST changes will not be released, so nothing to do.
(In reply to Stephan Herrmann from comment #51) > Szymon, I'm sorry if I've encouraged you to spend time on parts of the patch > that won't get released after all.
No problem. I had a chance to explore unexplored (for me) parts of JDT so it was definitely a very instructive journey :)
> Szymon, do you have a minute to prepare a final patch on short notice?
Sure. If I understand correctly, there are two things to be done: 1) replace HashtableOfObject with SimpleSetOfCharArray and 2) remove all DOM AST changes from the patch, so the patch should be ready today after local JDT tests pass. Which one do you prefer: a change in Gerrit or a patch on bugzilla?

(In reply to Stephan Herrmann from comment #51) > The part which I'd call border-line is where ImportRewrite.addImport throws > IllegalArgumentException. Szymon argues that these methods can already throw > IAE for other situations. Apparently, different parts in JDT/UI react > differently to this IAE.
ImportRewrite is part of the DOM and hence in the "don't release" bucket.
The IAEs that are currently thrown from add*Import*(*) methods are all API contract violations. Since strengthening preconditions is a breaking change, you cannot throw new IAEs from existing APIs. And even in a new API we would go the "best effort" way here.
Just to give you one potential usage example that explains why: Assume a CU from a 1.5 project needs to be moved to package p.enum in a 1.4 project. It would be perfectly fine to use an ImportRewrite on the original CU, call rewriteImports(*), and then apply the TextEdit to a document that will be saved in the 1.4 project.
Even if we would aim for the perfect solution, the checks would have to be done in the quick fix / refactoring implementations.
